original_email:
Hi there,

Just wanted to follow up again regarding the invoice we sent a while back — we haven’t seen any payment come through yet, so just checking if it’s been missed or if there are any issues we should know about.

Totally understand if things are busy on your end! Let us know if you need us to resend the invoice or if you have any questions about the details.

Thanks again and looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best,
The Team
final_prompt:
You are an assistant writing on behalf of AcmeHR, an Australian HR and EOR platform.
Use clear, confident language, and follow Australian English spelling and conventions.
Avoid Americanisms like 'organize' or 'color' — prefer 'organise', 'colour', etc.
When referring to business terms, use Australian-appropriate language where applicable.

Thanks again and looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best,

gemini_response:
ANALYSIS:
The original email is polite and professional, aiming for clarity and understanding. To effectively transform it into a "pirate" tone, we need to replace the formal language with more colourful, nautical expressions, and adopt a more assertive, perhaps slightly threatening, persona. The directness of the message should remain, but the delivery will be much more theatrical.

SUBJECT:
Ahoy, Matey! Where be our doubloons?

REWRITTEN EMAIL:
Ahoy there,

Just sendin' a cannonball across yer bow 'bout that invoice we sent some time ago, aye. We've not seen any o' yer hard-earned doubloons land in our coffers yet, so we're just checkin' if it's gone adrift or if there be any troubles brewin'.

Understand if ye be sailin' through rough seas, but don't be keelhauled for forgettin' yer debts! Let us know if ye need us to send the map to the treasure (resend the invoice), or if ye have any questions 'bout the booty.

Thanks again, and we be waitin' to hear from ye afore we send the Kraken.

Fair winds (and timely payments!),
The Crew at AcmeHR

gemini_response:
ANALYSIS:
The original email is overly casual and uses phrases like "Hi there," "a while back," and "Totally understand." While friendly, it lacks the directness and clarity expected in professional communication, particularly concerning invoices and payments.

SUBJECT:
Invoice [Invoice Number] - Payment Reminder

REWRITTEN EMAIL:

Dear [Client Name],

This email is a follow-up regarding invoice [Invoice Number], which was issued on [Date]. We have not yet received payment and are writing to ensure its receipt and address any potential issues.

Please confirm that payment is in progress, or let us know if you require a copy of the invoice to be resent. We are happy to clarify any details or answer any questions you may have.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
AcmeHR Team

ANALYSIS:
The original email uses extremely informal and unprofessional language, making it unsuitable for business communication. It lacks clarity and could be perceived as disrespectful.

SUBJECT:
Invoice [Invoice Number] - Payment Follow-Up

REWRITTEN EMAIL:

Dear [Client Name],

I hope this email finds you well.

We are following up on invoice [Invoice Number], which was sent on [Date]. We have not yet received payment and wanted to check if it has been overlooked or if there are any issues we should be aware of.

We understand that you may be busy. Please let us know if you require us to resend the invoice or if you have any questions regarding its details.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. We look forward to hearing from you soon.

Kind regards,

The AcmeHR Team
